content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple sections of tissue, likely lymph nodes, embedded in adipose (fat) tissue. There appear to be at least four to five separate lymph nodes. Several of these nodes contain large, darkly stained (basophilic) areas, which are highly suspicious for metastatic tumor deposits. The largest node in the upper left shows extensive replacement by this dark cellular infiltrate.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am examining the largest lymph node, which is the first one from the top-left. This node is highly suspicious for metastasis at low power due to the extensive basophilic area. I have zoomed into the margin of this suspicious area to confirm the nature of the cells. This interface is crucial for distinguishing between a reactive process and a malignancy, and also to assess for extranodal extension (tumor spreading beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat), which is a key prognostic feature. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located within the largest central lymph node, which shows significant basophilia at low power. This appearance is highly suggestive of a positive lymph node. The purpose of zooming in is to examine the cellular morphology at high magnification to confirm the presence of metastatic carcinoma cells and assess the extent of nodal replacement. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is placed on one of the lymph nodes in the lower right quadrant. This node, like others in the field, shows a significant dark purple infiltrate, raising suspicion for metastatic disease. I would zoom into this area to closely examine the cellular morphology of the infiltrate to confirm if it represents metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma or another process, such as a reactive lymphoid hyperplasia or a lymphoma, and to assess for extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to examine every lymph node to screen for metastasis. This particular area, located in the lower right, is one of the lymph nodes that appears highly suspicious at low power due to its dark, solid appearance. I am zooming in to assess the cellular morphology in detail to determine if the cells are benign lymphocytes or malignant metastatic tumor cells, and to evaluate the extent of involvement. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic examination of all submitted lymph nodes. This particular node, located on the right side of the image, shows a dense, solid, dark purple region that nearly replaces the entire node. This appearance is highly suspicious for a positive lymph node, where normal lymphoid architecture is effaced by metastatic carcinoma. The zoom is aimed at the interface between the dense cellular area and the surrounding fat to assess the cells' morphology and look for potential extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense infiltrate of atypical cells with large, dark (hyperchromatic), and irregularly shaped nuclei. These cells are arranged in solid sheets and are infiltrating the surrounding adipose tissue (the large, clear, circular spaces). While distinct gland formation is not apparent in this specific field, the cytologic features are consistent with a poorly differentiated carcinoma. My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma in a lymph node, confirming it as a positive node. The infiltration into the fat also indicates the presence of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is almost completely effaced. It has been replaced by dense sheets of atypical cells with large, dark (hyperchromatic), and pleomorphic nuclei. The cells are crowded and show a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. Interspersed are clear spaces, which are fat cells from the perinodal adipose tissue or intranodal fat. My impression is that this is a lymph node massively infiltrated by metastatic carcinoma, confirming it is a positive node.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, there is a dense, monotonous infiltrate of small, dark-staining cells with round nuclei and scant cytoplasm, consistent with small lymphocytes. These cells are infiltrating the lymph node architecture and extending into the surrounding adipose tissue (the large white circular spaces). I do not see the typical features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as glandular structures, large pleomorphic cells, or significant necrosis. Instead, the morphology is highly suggestive of a lymphoproliferative disorder, such as Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) / Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). This appears to be an incidental or co-existing hematologic malignancy rather than a metastasis from the colorectal primary.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal lymph node architecture is almost completely replaced by dense sheets of small, round, darkly stained (hyperchromatic) cells with scant cytoplasm. These cells are monotonous and do not form glandular structures, suggesting a poorly differentiated carcinoma or possibly a neuroendocrine tumor. The tumor cells are seen infiltrating the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue (the large white circular spaces are fat cells). My impression is that this is a lymph node positive for metastatic carcinoma, with extranodal extension.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a lymph node that is extensively infiltrated by a dense, monotonous sheet of small, round, dark-staining cells. These cells are seen infiltrating the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue on the left. Black pigment, likely tattoo ink from a prior colonoscopy or carbon pigment, is also present at the interface. The infiltrating cells have features more consistent with small lymphocytes rather than typical colorectal adenocarcinoma cells (which are usually larger, have more cytoplasm, and form glands). While the extensive infiltration and effacement of the node are very suspicious for metastasis, the cytology itself is not classic for carcinoma. This could represent a lymph node completely replaced by tumor, but it could also be a florid reactive process or even a lymphoma. Further examination of other areas and potentially immunohistochemistry (e.g., for cytokeratins) would be required to make a definitive diagnosis.
